member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Content.AssetLoadHelper
member.summary: Helps to determine when an asset with shared resources is fully loaded.

remarks.para: Shared resources (see ) are loaded deferred. When the method returns, shared resources might not yet be loaded. An keeps track of the loading of shared resources for a specific asset. An raises an event when all fix-up actions have been executed and all shared resources have been loaded. This event can be used to initialize an asset as soon as it is loaded including all shared resources.
Each asset has a certain which can be retrieved by calling . Any fixup actions of the asset must be wrapped using (see example below).

WARNING: The can only be used to track shared resources when it is guaranteed that they have a value that is not . This is a limitation by the XNA Framework. (When a shared resource is loaded by calling the fix-up action only gets executed, when it has a value other than . When the value is the fix-up action will never get executed and the will never realize that the loading of the asset has finished.)

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardNormal
member.summary: Defines the normal vector of a billboard.
member.remarks: Billboards are oriented, textured polygons. The billboard orientation is usually defined by two vectors: the normal vector and the axis vector. The normal vector of a billboard is the vector that points away from the billboard plane, usually towards the viewpoint (camera). The enumeration defines which normal vector is used for rendering.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardNormal.ViewPlaneAligned
member.summary: The billboard normal is parallel to the view vector of the camera, but points in the opposite direction (= towards the camera). The billboard is always parallel to the view plane (screen) and rotates when the orientation of the camera changes.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardNormal.ViewpointOriented
member.summary: The billboard normal vector points from the center of the billboard towards the camera (viewpoint). The billboard always faces the camera and rotates when the position of the camera changes.

summary.para: The billboard normal is specified explicitly.
The billboard normal is specified differently depending on the type of billboard:

item.description: The normal vector of a regular billboard is given by the . The normal vector is the local z-axis (0, 0, 1) of the scene node.
The normal vector of particles is defined by a particle parameter. The needs to have a uniform or varying particle parameter called "Normal".

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation
member.summary: Defines the orientation of a billboard.

remarks.para: Billboards are oriented, textured polygons (usually quads) used for drawing particles and other effects. Billboards can have various orientations depending on the type of effect.
The class defines various standard orientations, but can also be used to define custom billboard orientations.
The orientation of a billboard is defined by two vectors: the normal vector and the axis vector.

description.para: The normal vector of a billboard is the vector that points away from the billboard plane, usually towards the viewpoint (camera). The property is an enumeration that defines how the normal vector is chosen.
If not chosen automatically, the normal vector of a regular is given by the . The normal vector is defined by the local z-axis (0, 0, 1) of the scene node.
The normal vector of particles is defined by a particle parameter. The needs to have a uniform or varying particle parameter called "Normal".

The axis vector of a billboard is a vector that lies in the billboard plane. All billboard rotations are relative to this vector. Normally, the up-vector in world space or view space is used. Different axis vectors must be used for effects that have a direction (e.g. laser beams). determines if this vectors is interpreted as a vector in view space or in world space.
The axis vector of a regular is set in defined by the . The axis vector is given by the local up direction (0, 1, 0) of the scene node.
The axis vector of particles is defined by a particle parameter. The needs to have a uniform or varying particle parameter called "Axis".

remarks.para: If the normal and the axis vectors are not perpendicular, then one vector is kept constant and the second vector is made orthonormal to the first vector. For most effects, the normal vector should be the fixed axis (e.g. fire, smoke). For billboards with a fixed direction in world space (e.g. distant trees), the axis vector should be the fixed vector. The property determines, which axis is fixed.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.ScreenAligned
member.summary: Settings for screen-aligned billboards.

remarks.para: Screen-aligned billboards have the same orientation as the screen: They are always parallel to the view plane and the axis vector matches the up-axis of the screen.
Examples using : Text labels, which should always be readable and therefore need to have the same orientation as the screen.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.ViewPlaneAligned
member.summary: Settings for view plane-aligned billboards.

remarks.para: View plane-aligned billboards are used to render most particle effects: The billboards are always parallel to the view plane (screen) and rotate with the camera. If not specified explicitly, the billboard axis is the up vector (0, 1, 0) in world space.
Examples using : Fire, smoke, etc.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.ViewpointOriented
member.summary: Settings for viewpoint-oriented billboards.
member.remarks:
Viewpoint-oriented billboards are always oriented to face the viewpoint (camera position). If not specified explicitly, the billboard axis is the up vector (0, 1, 0) in world space.
Examples using : Impostors for large, distant objects such clouds.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.WorldOriented
member.summary: Settings for billboards with a free orientation in world space.
member.remarks:
The orientation is defined by the normal vector and the axis vector. These two billboard vectors define a fixed orientation in world space.
Examples using : foliage with a fixed orientation, or decals.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.AxialViewPlaneAligned
member.summary: Settings for axial billboards parallel to the view plane.

remarks.para: Axial billboards are also known as constrained billboards or cylindrical billboards. The billboard axis is given in world space. Billboards are rotated around the billboard axis to face the view plane. If not specified explicitly, the billboard axis is the up vector (0, 1, 0) in world space.
Examples using : Impostors close to the camera such as grass.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.BillboardOrientation.AxialViewpointOriented
member.summary: Settings for axial billboards oriented towards the viewer.

remarks.para: Axial billboards are also known as constrained billboards or cylindrical billboards. The billboard axis is the up-axis in world space. Billboards are rotated around the billboard axis towards the viewpoint. If not specified explicitly, the billboard axis is the up vector (0, 1, 0) in world space.
Examples using : Impostors far away from the camera such as distant trees.

remarks.para: When rendering mirrors or portals, the objects before the mirror or portal should not be rendered. This could be solved using clip planes, but these clip planes need to be supported by all shaders. Alternatively, we can also solve this problem by creating a view frustum where the near plane is parallel to the clip plane - such frustums are called oblique view frustums because the near plane (and also the far plane) are tilted compared to standard view frustums.
Use the property to set a clip plane for the near view-plane. Setting a near clip plane changes the projection matrix. However, it does not affect the shape (see ) of the !
For general information about oblique view frustums, see .

remarks.para: The can be used to define complex shapes composed of lines and curves. The figure is 2D and lies in the xy plane where x-axis points to the right and y-axis points upwards. The curve segments need to be added to the collection. A curve segment is any object that implements ICurve<float, Vector2F>. Examples: , , , ...

Fill:
Closed shapes within the figure can be filled: A closed shape is defined by consecutive, connected curve segments. For example: Four can be used to create a filled rectangle. The end of the previous segment needs to match the start of the next segment. The last segment of a closed shape needs to be connected with the first segment.
The property determines whether closed shapes will be filled. (The property is by default.)

Stroked vs. Unstroked Segments:
By default all curve segments are stroked meaning that the curve segment will be rendered with a given stroke color and thickness. The can be used to add a curve segment which is not stroked. This class is a decorator that wraps a curve segment and allows to define whether it is stroked or not.

remarks.para: A lens flare is an effect caused by a camera lens when looking at bright light. A lens flare usually consists of multiple elements which move across the screen depending on the position of the light source: bloom and halo around the light source, light streaks, secondary rings, hexagonal patterns caused by the lens' aperture blades. member.remarks:
Normal ambient lighting does not depend on the direction of the normal vector of the lit surface. Hemispheric lighting depends on the normal vector and the up vector of the light: A lit surface point is brightest if the normal points is parallel to the up vector, and it is darkest if the normal is orthogonal to the light's up vector or pointing in the down direction.
If is 0, this light is ambient light without hemispheric attenuation. If is 1, this light is a hemispheric light. Usually, is set to a value in between. For example, if it is set to 0.7, then every surface point is lit with at least 30% intensity and only surface points with up point normals are lit with 100% intensity.

Diffuse light intensity Ldiffuse = ColorRGB Â· DiffuseIntensity Â· HdrScale

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.ImageBasedLight
member.summary: Represents a light which uses an environment cube map to add diffuse lighting and specular lighting (reflections).
member.remarks:
Image-based lighting (IBL) uses a cube map of the environment to define the lighting in a scene.
The property defines the used environment map. This property must be set to valid cube map- otherwise, the is disabled. The texture can be a normal sRGB texture or an RGBM encoded HDR texture; see . The cube map must contain mipmaps.
When a mesh is shaded, the normal vector is used to look up a color value in the environment map to use for diffuse lighting. Reflection vectors are used to look up color values for specular lighting. This allows a mesh to reflect the environment, like a mirror. The mipmap levels are used to create reflections on materials with different glossiness. Materials with a high , like mirrors, use high resolution mipmap levels. Diffuse lighting and dull materials use low resolution mipmap levels.
s have a , which can be or a . Lights with an infinite shape cover the whole scene. Usually a level contains only one image-based light with an infinite shape. Lights with a box shape cover only the volume inside the box. This allows to set different image-based lights for different rooms or zones of a level.
A must be used to add an to a scene. The is also used to define the position and the orientation of the light.
The determines if the diffuse light contribution of an image-based light is added to the scene (additive blending, = 0) or replaces the ambient lighting and other image-based lights (alpha blending, = 1). The default is = 1, which means that an diffuse light replaces the ambient lighting and other image-based lights.
Note: Image-based lights are usually applied after the ambient light of the scene and before the other lights of the scene. Image-based lights never replace other lights, like directional lights or point lights.
The property can be used to let an image-based light fade out to create smooth blending between different image-based lights or between an image-based light and an area which contains no image-based lights. (Only relevant for box-shaped lights. Infinite lights never fade out.)
Image-based lights have color and intensity, which are used to tint and scale the colors of the environment map. The color of the , the , / and are multiplied to get the final diffuse and specular light intensities which can be used in the lighting equations.
Diffuse only: The can be set to to disable the specular light contribution. This creates a pure diffuse light. As mentioned above, the determines whether the diffuse light is added to the scene ( = 0) or replaces the ambient light and other image-based lights ( = 1).
Specular only: The can be set to to disable the diffuse light contribution. This creates a pure specular light, which can be used for reflections only.
Localized reflections:Usually, environment maps are treated as if the scene in the environment map is infinitely far away. If an image-based light is used to create reflection of a box-shaped room, the reflections will not properly align with the walls of the room. To correct the reflections, can be set to . In this case the reflections are computed to fit a given box. This box is either equal to the of the light (property ) or to an axis-aligned box defined by . The box is always aligned with the local space of the .
Cloning:When the is cloned the and the are not duplicated. These properties are copied by reference.
Usage tips:
If you only want to add environment map reflections to a game level, add one infinite image-based light with diffuse intensity set to . This way the light only adds reflections and does not influence the ambient light of the scene.
Image-based lights with a diffuse intensity can be used to replace ambient lighting. Ambient lighting is usually very "flat", e.g. an ambient light adds only one color. An image-based light can create more interesting ambient lighting. For example, if the environment map contains the blue sky and a brown ground, then objects lit by the image-based light will be blue on top and brown at the bottom.
Image-based lights can also be used to add "light bounces". For example, if the environment map contains a yellow wall, objects near the yellow wall will receive a yellow "bounce light".
Environment maps defined by image-based lights can be used in effects using the environment map semantics, see e.g. .
To get proper reflections in rooms, create one image-based light per room. Set to . Set an AABB in which is aligned with the floor, ceiling and walls of the room. s can be rotated to align with rooms which are not axis-aligned with the world space.
It is recommended to position the image-based lights at the eye-level of the player and to capture the environment maps from this position.
If you want to smoothly fade out an image-based light over time, you can fade the from 1 (alpha-blend) to 0 (additive), and at the same time fade the and to 0. This creates a smooth change in lighting.

The angle at which the light is cut off (light intensity is 0) is defined as the . So the size of the inner cone is 2 Â· and the size of the outer cone is 2 Â· . See also .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Material
member.summary: Defines the material (visual properties) of a mesh.

remarks.para: A represents the geometry and materials of a 3D object that can be rendered. A mesh owns a collection of and is divided into es. Each describes a batch of primitives (usually triangles) that use one material and can be rendered with a single draw call.

An effect binding (see class ) provides the render states required for each draw call: An that defines the graphics device states. A technique binding selects the vertex and pixel shaders for rendering. And parameter bindings define static properties (color, diffuse texture, gloss map, normal map, etc.) as well as dynamic properties (world/view/projection matrices, light properties, etc.). But depending on the render pipeline that is used, multiple render passes may be required to draw a certain object. Therefore, a is a dictionary of effect bindings - one effect binding per render pass. The dictionary key is the name of the render pass (a case-sensitive string such as "Default", "ZPass", "ShadowMap", "GBuffer", "Material", etc.). The dictionary value is the that contains required settings for this render pass. The entries in a material depend on the type of renderer that is used.
Example: A forward renderer usually only requires a single render pass, in which the mesh is rendered into the back buffer. In this case the material contains one entry (Key = "Default", Value = ).

Advanced example: A light pre-pass renderer usually requires several render passes per mesh: In the "ShadowMap" pass the mesh is rendered into the shadow-map texture, which is used later on. Then in the "GBuffer" pass the depth, the normals, and other properties of the mesh are rendered into multiple render targets. Next, the renderer computes the lighting information. Then in the "Material" pass, the mesh is rendered again - the lighting information is combined with the material settings. In this example the material contains 3 entries. The keys are "GBuffer", "Material", and "ShadowMap".
A is not bound to a certain . It can be shared by different objects.
Important: When an is used as part of a , then it can only contain parameter bindings with the sort hint (see ).

Cloning:
s can be cloned. When is called all are duplicated (deep copy).

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Mesh
member.summary: Represents a mesh of a 3D model.

remarks.para: A mesh represents the geometry and materials of a 3D object that can be rendered. A mesh owns a collection of and is divided into es. Each describes a batch of primitives (usually triangles) that use one material and can be rendered with a single draw call.
The mesh can be rendered by creating a and adding it to a 3D scene.
Morph Target Animation: Submeshes may include morph targets (see ). The extension method can be used to get a list of all morph targets included in a mesh. The current are stored in the .

Skeletal Animation: The mesh may contain a , which can be used to animate (deform) the mesh. The current is stored in the . The property can be animated. A set of key frame animations can be stored in .

Bounding shape: The bounding shape of the mesh is usually created by the content pipeline and stored in the property. It is not updated automatically when the vertex buffer changes. The user who changes the vertex buffer is responsible for updating or replacing the shape stored in . If the mesh can be deformed on the GPU (e.g. using mesh skinning), then the bounding shape must be large enough to contain all possible deformations.
The properties of the bounding shape can be changed at any time. But it is not allowed to replace the bounding shape while the is in use, i.e. referenced by a scene node.

For example, if the bounding shape is a , the radius of the sphere can be changed at any time. But it is not allowed to replace the with a as long as the mesh is used in a scene. Replacing the bounding shape will not raise any exceptions, but the mesh may no longer be rendered correctly.
Cloning: Meshes are currently not cloneable.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.MorphTarget
member.summary: Defines a morph target (blend shape) of a submesh.

remarks.para: Morph target animation (or per-vertex animation, blend shape interpolation) can be used to deform a model. It is primarily used for facial animation.

The defines the base shape (neutral expression). A defines a deformed version of the base shape. Morph target animation typically involves several morph targets where each morph target represents a key shape (expressions such as "smile", "closed eye", "raised eyebrow"). A weight, usually in the range [0, 1], is assigned to each morph target. These weights control the influence of the morph targets and are animated over time. When the model is rendered the vertices are interpolated between the submesh and the morph targets.

The submesh and the corresponding morph targets need to have the same structure. That is, the order of the vertices in the needs to match the order of the vertices in the submesh. The of morph target stores vertices of type . Vertex positions and normals are relative to the submesh (difference between key shape and base shape, "delta shape").
The morph target weights of a specific mesh instance are stored in the (see property ). These weights are used during rendering.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Teapot
member.summary: "The" teapot.
member.remarks: This teapot model was created by Martin Newell and Jim Blinn in 1975. It consists of ten cubic BÃ©zier patches, a type of curved surface which can be tessellated to create triangles at various levels of detail. The use of curved surfaces allows a smoothly curved, visually interesting, and instantly recognizable shape to be specified by a tiny amount of data, which made the teapot a popular test data set for computer graphics researchers. It has been used in so many papers and demos that many graphics programmers have come to think of it as a standard geometric primitive, right up there with cubes and spheres!

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Teapot.TeapotPatch
member.summary: The teapot model consists of 10 BÃ©zier patches. Each patch has 16 control points, plus a flag indicating whether it should be mirrored in the Z axis as well as in X (all of the teapot is symmetrical from left to right, but only some parts are symmetrical from front to back). The control points are stored as integer indices into the TeapotControlPoints array.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Occluder
member.summary: Defines an occluder represented as an indexed triangle mesh.

remarks.para: Occlusion culling is the process of determining which scene nodes are hidden from a certain viewpoint. This is achieved by testing the scene nodes against a set of occluders. An occluder is an object within a scene that obscures the view and prevents objects behind it from being seen. In theory, any opaque object within a scene acts as occluder. However, most scene nodes (e.g. meshes) are too complex to be considered as occluders during occlusion culling.

Occlusion Proxies:
The class defines a triangle mesh that acts as an occluder for occlusion culling. An is usually a lightweight representations of more complex scene node. Example: An storing a simple quad (2 triangles) can be used to approximate a complex wall (mesh with many triangles).

An occluder can be assigned to a (property ) or can be added directly to a scene using an . The is often attached as child node to the scene node that it represents. This ensures that the occluder is updated automatically when the parent scene node is moved.
The occluder geometry needs to be conservative, i.e. the triangle mesh needs to fit inside the object that it represents. Otherwise it may prevent visible objects from being rendered.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow
member.summary: Defines a cascaded shadow that can be used for s.

remarks.para: A cascaded shadow map splits the camera frustum into separate slices (up to 4). For each slice a shadow map is computed.

A "slice" is also called "cascade interval", "sub-frustum" or simply "cascade". The word "cascade" actually means "a series of stages" - however, it is common to use the term "cascade" to describe an individual slice and this term is used here too.
The term "split" could refer to the border between two slices (4 cascades = 3 splits) or to the slices (cascade = split). Therefore, the term "split" has to be used with care.
defines the cascade split distances and the maximum shadow distance.
defines the size of a single cascade of the cascaded shadow map.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.NumberOfCascades
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of cascades.
member.value: The number of cascades (1 - 4). The default value is 4.
member.exception: is less than 1 or greater than 4.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.Distances
member.summary: Gets or sets the cascade split distances.
member.value: The cascade split distances in world space. The default value is (4, 12, 20, 80).

remarks.para: This vector contains the distances where the camera frustum is split in world space in following order: (split 0-1, split 1-2, split 2-3, max shadow distance). If the is less than 4, then the last components are ignored.

For example, if is (4, 12, 20, 80), then the first cascade covers an area 4 units in front of the camera. The second cascade covers an area up to 12 units. The third cascade covers the area up to 20 units. The last cascade always covers the remaining area. The max. shadow distance is 80. The renderer does not need to render shadows beyond 80 units in front of the camera.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.MinLightDistance
member.summary: Gets or sets the minimal distance of the light projection to the camera frustum of a cascade.
member.value: The minimum light distance from the camera frustum. The default value is 100.
member.remarks: To compute the shadow map an orthographic projection is fitted to the partial frustum of a cascade. The near plane of this orthographic projection should be moved as close as possible to the cascade - but not too close in order to catch occluders in front of the cascade. defines the minimum allowed distance of the shadow projection near plane from the cascade.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.DepthBias
member.summary: Gets or sets the depth bias used to remove "surface acne".
member.value: The depth bias for each of the 4 cascades in shadow map texels. The default value is (5, 5, 5, 5).

remarks.para: This value is used to modify the depth value of the shadow-receiving pixel. A positive value moves the receiver closer to the light source (into the light), a negative value moves the receiver farther away from the light source (into the shadow). If this value is too large, the shadow becomes visually disconnected from the occluder (a.k.a. "Peter Panning").

This value is relative to the shadow map resolution. A depth bias of 1 changes the depth by the size of one shadow map texel. Therefore, the depth bias values automatically scale with the shadow map resolution of each cascade. You can set 4 different values to tune the depth bias for each cascade.

The is used to remove "surface acne" at surfaces facing the light source. The is used to remove "surface acne" at steep angles, i.e. surface parallel to the light direction. In practice a combination of and is required to remove shadow artifacts.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.NormalOffset
member.summary: Gets or sets the normal offset used to remove "surface acne".
member.value: The normal offset for each of the 4 cascades in shadow map texels. The default value is (2, 2, 2, 2).

remarks.para: This value is used to modify the position of shadow receivers. This has the effect of moving the receiver into the direction of the receiver's surface normal. This helps to remove "surface acne" especially on steep slopes. If this value is too high, the shadow becomes visually disconnected from the occluder (a.k.a. "Peter Panning").

This value is relative to the shadow map resolution. A normal offset of 1 moves the position by the size of one shadow map texel. Therefore, the normal offset values automatically scale with the shadow map resolution of each cascade. You can set 4 different values to tune the normal offset for each cascade.

The is used to remove "surface acne" at surfaces facing the light source. The is used to remove "surface acne" at steep angles, i.e. surface parallel to the light direction. In practice a combination of and is required to remove shadow artifacts.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.NumberOfSamples
member.summary: Gets or sets the number of filter samples.
member.value: The number of PCF samples. The default value is -1 (see remarks).
member.remarks: If this value is -1 (default), the shadow mask renderer will use predefined and optimized sampling pattern. If this value is 0, the shadow map is sampled once without any PCF (percentage closer filtering). If this value is 1, the shadow map is sampled with one jittered sample without any PCF. If this value is greater than 1, the shadow map is sampled with the given number of PCF samples.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.FilterRadius
member.summary: Gets or sets the filter radius.
member.value: The filter radius in texels. The default value of is 1.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.JitterResolution
member.summary: Gets or sets the jitter resolution (for jitter sampling).
member.value: The jitter resolution. The jitter resolution is the number of noise texels per world space unit. The default value is 2048.
member.remarks: This value is only used when jitter sampling is applied to filter shadow edges. Jitter sampling uses a noise pattern to choose which shadow map texels are sampled. This noise is stable in world space. The defines the size of the jitter pattern relative to the world. If the jitter resolution is too high, then the noise becomes visually unstable when the camera moves (because there are too many noise pixels per screen pixel). Low jitter resolutions can cause a coarse blocky noise patterns.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.CascadedShadow.FadeOutRange
member.summary: Gets or sets the relative distance over which shadows are faded out.

remarks.para: These flags can be used to control shadow map caching. IsCascadeLocked[i] determines if the updates the cascade with index i or if it reuses the cached shadow map. Per default, all flags are and the shadow maps of all cascades are updated every frame. If the flag of a cascade is set to , the shadow map of the cascade is not rendered; the result of the last frame is used instead. The application can use this flags to determine when cascades need to be updated. (Note: If a flag is changed, it keeps this value until it is changed again. The flags are not automatically reset.)

list.item: Update distant cascades less often.
Do not update a cascade if it does not contain any dynamic objects and if the camera has not move.

remarks.para: A cloud map defines a cloud texture using (up to) 8 s, which are sampled and added together. The resulting cloud texture is stored in . A cloud map layer can contain a texture or random noise. In addition, layers can be animated. See for more information.
To disable a cloud map layer, simply set the array entry to or the of the layer to 0.

The class only defines the settings for generating a cloud texture and stores the result, but it does not automatically generate the cloud texture. member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Terrain
member.summary: Represents a height field based terrain. (Not available on these platforms: Xbox 360, mobile platforms)

remarks.para: This type is not available on the following platforms: Xbox 360, mobile platforms

A terrain is split into one or more tiles. The terrain tiles defines the geometry (height, normals, holes) of the terrain. Each tile has a set of material layers (dirt, grass, decals, roads) that define the appearance. The material layers are applied (blended) one after the other, which means that a layer can override previous layers.
See and for more information.

Cache invalidation:
When the is used with the , then the terrain data is cached in clipmaps. Therefore, it is important to notify the terrain system when a tile or layer has changed and the cached data is invalid. When tiles or layers are added to or removed from the terrain, this happens automatically. But when the properties or the contents of tiles/layers are changed, the affected region needs to be invalidated explicitly by calling the appropriate method of the or the . For example, when the contents of a height map is changed, the affected region on the terrain needs to be invalidated by calling or .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainClipmap
member.summary: Represents a clipmap which stores terrain data.

remarks.para: For a basic introduction to clipmaps, see Clipmaps (Wikipedia).

The clipmap can store geometry information (e.g. heights, normals, holes) or material information (e.g. diffuse color, specular color). The usage of a clipmap can vary and is not defined by this class itself. The only restriction is that all textures of this clipmap use the same texture format.

The clipmap consists of several levels, which are similar to mipmap levels. Level 0 has the finest resolution. All other levels have a lower resolution. The cell size (= texel size) is usually doubled between levels, but this can be configured using the property . For example: A clipmap which stores terrain height values can use a resolution of 1 meter per cell at level 0, 2 meters per cell at level 1, 4 meters per cell at level 2, etc.
There is one texture for each clipmap level. All texture have the same size which is defined by . The number of levels is defined by .

Further a clipmap can consist of several textures per level, e.g. one texture to store detail normal vectors, a second texture to store diffuse color, a third texture to store specular color. Because of XNA limitations it might be necessary to combine several textures into a single texture atlas, where each texture atlas contains all levels with the same content. For example: One texture atlas contains all level textures with detail normal vectors, a second texture atlas contains all level textures with diffuse colors, the third texture atlas contains all level textures with specular colors. - All textures can be accessed using the collection. (It can be helpful to visualize the textures for debugging).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainClipmap.CellSizes
member.summary: Gets the cell sizes of all clipmap levels.
member.value: The cell sizes of all clipmap levels.

remarks.para: This array contains elements - where only the first elements are used.

The first element CellSizes[0] has to be set. All other entries can contain NaN values, which means that subsequent cell sizes are chosen automatically. By default, each cell size is twice the cell size of the previous level.

Example: The array contains the values { 1, NaN, NaN, NaN, NaN, ... }. In this case the first level uses a cell size of 1 unit. The second level has a cell size of 2 units. The third level has a cell size of 4 units per cell. Etc.

The default terrain renderers ( and ) use only CellSizes[0] for the (all other cell sizes are treated as if they are NaN or twice the size of the previous level). The can have user-defined cell sizes for all levels.

member.summary: Binds an effect parameter to a value of a given type.
member.typeparam: The value type. Must be one of the following types: , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , , .

remarks.para: and are the base implementations of all parameter bindings of type . Classes derived from are used to bind effect parameters that represent a single value (such as , , etc.). Classes that are derived from are used to bind effect parameters that represent arrays of values.

and should be used when the value of the effect parameter is static or updated manually. The value can be set directly. The binding ensures that the parameter is applied whenever the needs to be rendered.
and need to be used when the value of the effect parameter is dynamic and should be updated automatically.
and are dummy bindings that do not modify effect parameters. These bindings can be set, if parameters should not be updated automatically.
User-defined bindings can be implemented by deriving from , , or to define new mechanisms for resolving effect parameter values.

Notes to Inheritors:
The static constructors of and automatically validate the value type and checks whether the type is supported.

Inheritors should override when the value of the effect parameter needs to be updated before rendering. The new value computed in must be stored in . (It is not necessary to call of the base class in the derived class.)

By default, assigns the current to by using the appropriate EffectParameter.SetValue() method. Inheritors can override this method to perform additional work. It is necessary to call of the base class to ensure that the value is properly set.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Effects.EffectParameterDescription
member.summary: Describes a parameter of an effect.

remarks.para: s provide additional information for effect parameters. This information is used by the graphics engine to understand effects and apply them properly during rendering.

The standard semantic (see ) is a unique, case-sensitive string (such as "World", "Diffuse", "PointLightPosition", etc.) that defines how the parameter should be interpreted and used by the engine. User-defined strings can be used, as long as they do not conflict with any of the existing semantics. Existing semantics are defined by the following types: , .

The index (see ) defines the object to which the parameter needs to be bound if multiple objects of the same type exist. The description ( = "PointLightPosition", = 3, = ) means that the parameter stores the position of 4th point light near the object that is being rendered.
Additionally, the sort hint (see ) indicates how the parameter should be treated during state sorting.

The descriptions are created automatically by effect interpreters (see ) when an effect is initialized. The graphics service manages a list of effect interpreters. Custom interpreters can be added to the graphics service to support new types of effects.

member.summary: Indicates how an effect parameter should be treated during state sorting.

remarks.para: The sorts meshes by render states before rendering them. State sorting is used to minimize number of state changes required for drawing a complex scene.
Each effect parameter has an . The sort hint is a value indicating how the effect parameter should be treated during state sorting. It basically puts each parameter into a certain category.

The sort hint is stored in the effect parameter description (see ). The parameter descriptions of an effect can be read using the method . The value is set by one of the effect interpreters (see ) of the graphics service (see ) during effect initialization.

member.name: F:DigitalRune.Graphics.Effects.EffectParameterHint.Local

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Effects.EffectBinding
member.summary: Provides the logic for rendering a specific .

remarks.para: An defines the render states required to render an object. An provides the logic that is required for using an effect at runtime.
Multiple s can share the same . An can in theory be shared by different graphics objects. But in most cases an belongs to a single object, such as a .

Technique and Parameter Bindings:
An effect may define one or more effect techniques. When rendering a certain object the correct technique needs to be chosen. In addition, an effect defines a set of effect parameters. An effect file (.fx) can define default values for effect parameters. However, most effect parameters need to be set at runtime. Static parameters (such as colors, textures, etc.) can be set when assets are loaded. Dynamic parameters (such as world matrix, view matrix, projection matrix, etc.) need to be updated, typically once per frame, when the associated objects are rendered.
Effect parameters belong to different categories, defined by . An can be used to manage all kinds of effect parameters, or only parameters of a certain type, e.g. only parameters. See also .

DigitalRune Graphics introduces the concept of effect technique bindings and effect parameter bindings: The technique binding (see property ) provides the logic for selecting a technique at runtime. Parameter bindings (stored in ) links a effect parameters to a certain values. By using a a parameter can be bound to a static value. By using a a parameter can be dynamically updated when needed. Effect technique and parameter bindings are evaluated when the associated object (e.g. a mesh) needs to be rendered. Evaluation consists of two phases:
Update: The effect technique is selected; the new value of an effect parameter is calculated.
Apply: An effect technique is selected for rendering; the new value is applied to the effect parameter in .

Initialization: When an effect binding is created all technique and parameter bindings are created automatically. This initialization involves two steps:
Interpretation: s are used to interpret the meaning of effect techniques and parameters. An returns s and s which indicate how the effect should be used at runtime. This information is stored per effect and can also be queried using the methods and .
Binding of Effect Parameters: s read the information provided in the previous step and create an for the effect and s for all effect parameters.
The s and the s are stored in the . Custom interpreters/binders can be added to support new types of effects.

Cloning:
s need to be cloneable. The method calls and which are responsible for creating a clone of the current instance. Classes that derive from need to provide the implementation for and override if necessary.
By default, when an is cloned all technique and parameter bindings are duplicated (deep copy). Any optional object stored in is copied per reference (shallow copy).

member.summary: Defines the standard semantics for default effect parameters.

remarks.para: The standard semantic define the meaning of effect parameters. See .

Important: General semantics specified in an .fx files are case-insensitive. Therefore, use the string comparer for parsing .fx files. But when accessed from code (C# or VB.NET) the strings are case-sensitive! That means the standard semantics stored in can be compared directly.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Effects.SceneEffectParameterSemantics
member.summary: Defines the standard semantics for effect parameters used in a .

remarks.para: The standard semantic define the meaning of effect parameters. See .

Important: General semantics specified in an .fx files are case-insensitive. Therefore, use the string comparer for parsing .fx files. But when accessed from code (C# or VB.NET) the strings are case-sensitive! That means the standard semantics stored in can be compared directly.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainLayer
member.summary: Defines a material layer (detail textures, decals, roads, etc.) of the terrain.

remarks.para: A terrain is split into one or more tiles. The terrain tiles defines the geometry (height, normals, holes) of the terrain. Each tile has a set of material layers (dirt, grass, decals, roads) that define the appearance. The material layers are applied (blended) one after the other, which means that a layer can override previous layers.

Example: The first layer draws a dirt texture that covers the whole tile. The second layer draws a grass texture, which covers only parts of the tile defined by a blend map. Additional layers add roads and decals like dirt, leaves, sewer grates, etc.
Each terrain tile can have its own set of terrain layers, but they can also share the same instances.

Materials:
Each has a which is used to render the layer information. The uses the material to render the layer information into s. The requires that the material has a render pass called "Base" when it wants to render information, such as heights, into the and a render pass called "Detail" when it wants to render information, such as a grass texture, into the .

Fade-in/out by distance:
The properties , , , can be used to define into which clipmap levels the layer is rendered. For example if (, , , ) is (1, 3, 5, 7), then the layer is rendered into the clipmap level 1 with a low opacity. The opacity increases in level 2 and reaches 100% in level 3. The layer is rendered with full opacity in level 4. Then the opacity decreases again and reaches 0% at level 7. The default values are (0, 0, , ) which means that fading is disabled and the terrain layer is always visible at all distances.

These fade-in/out properties can be used to render details, like decals, only near the camera. It can also be used to have one layer draw a detailed rock texture only near the camera. Another layer can render a low resolution rock texture only in the distance.

The fade-in/out properties are based on clipmap levels and not view-distance. (The reason: If the distance depends on the camera, then all cached clipmaps have to be redrawn when the camera moves. This needs to be avoided.)

Cache invalidation:
When the is used with the , then the terrain data is cached in clipmaps. Therefore, it is important to notify the terrain system when a tile or layer has changed and the cached data is invalid. When tiles or layers are added to or removed from the terrain, this happens automatically. But when the properties or the contents of tiles/layers are changed, the affected region needs to be invalidated explicitly by calling the appropriate method of the or the . For example, when the contents of a height map is changed, the affected region on the terrain needs to be invalidated by calling or .

Disposing:
s are disposable. Derived classes should dispose all auto-generated resources. Resources set by the user or loaded via a content manager are not disposed by the .

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainMaterialLayer
member.summary: Represents a material with tiling textures that are rendered onto the terrain.

remarks.para: The renders a material, such as grass, dirt, rocks, etc., onto the terrain.

Material textures:
The material is defined by several tiling textures:
These textures repeat within the bounds of terrain tile. The property defines the scale of the textures.

Blend texture:
The contains blend weights. It is a non-tiling texture which covers the terrain tile. (In other tools or engines this texture is called splat map, control map, alpha map, material map, weight map, or mask texture.) A blend texture can contain several blend weights (e.g. an RGBA texture can contain 4 blend weights - one weight per channel). The property determines which channel is used by the material layer.

The material reads the blend weight from the blend texture and if the blend weight is greater than , the material is drawn. There is a small transition zone around the threshold where the material fades out. This transition zone is defined by .

The of the material can be used to modify the blending. This can be used to create more realistic transitions between two materials. For example: One material layer draws a dirt texture. The next material layer blends a stone texture over the dirt texture. The stone material includes a height texture. This is used to create a dirt-stone transition where more dirt is visible in the gaps between stones (low height values). controls how much the height texture influences the blending.

Noise can also be used to make transitions between two material layers visually more interesting. If is greater than 0, a noise value is added to the blend weight to make transitions less uniform. controls the size of the tiling noise texture.

Tint texture:
The contains a color that is multiplied with the material. Like the , the is a non-tiling texture which covers the entire terrain tile. defines the influence of the .

Height-based and slope-based blending based:
The properties , , , and can be used to apply the material only on terrain geometry with a certain height or slope. Near these limits the material fades out. The fade-out range is determined by and .

Triplanar texture mapping:
The material textures are usually projected top-down onto the material. This may lead to distorted textures on very steep slopes. Triplanar texture mapping can be used to reduce distortions. If the triplanar texturing is enabled, the terrain normals are checked and the texture is projected vertically (y direction) or horizontally (x or z direction) to minimize distortions.

Triplanar texture mapping is disabled by default ( = -1). Set to a positive value, e.g. 0.5, to enable triplanar texturing. Larger values make the transitions between different projection directions shorter.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainRoadLayer
member.summary: Represents a road which is rendered onto the terrain.

remarks.para: The renders a mesh which represents a road (or other road-like structures, e.g. skid marks). The road is represented by a which can be set using .

Material textures , , and are rendered along the road. The u-axis of the texture is mapped to the width of the road; the v-axis is mapped to the direction of the road. The textures are repeated along the road direction. The property determines the scale of tiling. (Textures are not tiled along the u-axis.)
The helper methods , and can be used to create a road mesh and to clamp a road mesh to a terrain or to carve a road into a terrain.

Important: The terrain road layer is only rendered on tiles where the layer is added. If the road stretches over multiple tiles, it needs to be added to all tiles. (An instance of can be shared by multiple terrain tiles.)

member.summary: Defines a for a which defines a road.

remarks.para: Roads (see ) are usually defined by 3D paths. A 3D path is a curve which goes through several path keys. Each path key defines a point on the curve and the spline interpolation between the point and the next point. When dealing with roads, you can use the class for the path keys to provide additional information.

defines the absolute with of the road at the path key. defines an additional border of the road where the road influences the terrain height. This property is used when the road is "carved" into a terrain (see . For example, if a road with a width of 5 and a side falloff of 4 is carved into a terrain, the center 5 units contain the actual road and the terrain height is adjusted to match the road. member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.TerrainTile
member.summary: Defines the geometry (height, normals, holes) and material of a rectangular terrain region.

remarks.para: A terrain is split into one or more tiles. The terrain tiles defines the geometry (height, normals, holes) of the terrain. Each tile has a set of material layers (dirt, grass, decals, roads) that define the appearance. The material layers are applied (blended) one after the other, which means that a layer can override previous layers.

Geometry textures:
The defines height values (absolute heights in world space) of the terrain.

contains the terrain normal vectors. This texture encodes the normal vectors like a standard "green-up" normal map, i.e. the world space +x component of the normal is stored in the red channel. The world space up (+y) component is stored in the blue channel. The negative world space z component is stored in the green channel.
defines holes in the terrain. The texture is used like an alpha mask texture. If the alpha channel contains 0, then there is a hole in the terrain.

Tile dimensions:
and define the tile origin in world space - which corresponds to center of the first texel of the textures. defines the horizontal distance between two height values. The texture coordinate u is aligned with the positive x-axis. The texture coordinate v is aligned with the positive z-axis. This means, if the cell/texel size is 1 world space unit and the texture is 1025 x 513 texels large, then the terrain tile covers the area between (OriginX, *, OriginZ) and (OriginX + 1024, *, OriginZ + 512).

Mipmaps:
All textures should contain mipmaps. Ideally, the mipmaps are generated using 3 x 3 downsampling instead of the usual 2 x 2 downsampling. - Suitable textures can be created using the class.

Miscellaneous:
Please notes that the normal vectors depend on the scale of the terrain. That means, if height values in the are scaled, then the normal map has to be updated too. The normal map also needs to be updated if the is changed! (This is not done automatically. Normal textures can be created using the .)
and should always be an integer multiple of the . For example, if the cell size is 0.5, valid origin values are -0.5, 0, 0.5, 1, etc.

Cache invalidation:
When the is used with the , then the terrain data is cached in clipmaps. Therefore, it is important to notify the terrain system when a tile or layer has changed and the cached data is invalid. When tiles or layers are added to or removed from the terrain, this happens automatically. But when the properties or the contents of tiles/layers are changed, the affected region needs to be invalidated explicitly by calling the appropriate method of the or the . For example, when the contents of a height map is changed, the affected region on the terrain needs to be invalidated by calling or .
See and for more information.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.OceanWaves
member.summary: Represents ocean waves computed using Fast Fourier Transformation and a statistical wave spectrum.

remarks.para: This class uses Fast Fourier Transformation (FFT) on the GPU to compute waves from many (several thousand) sine waves. The input wave spectrum is defined by a statistical spectrum of ocean waves. The defines the number of waves which are computed. If is 256, then the 256 x 256 waves are evaluated! The resulting wave textures tile seamlessly.

This class only stores the settings and final textures. The must be used to generated the textures at runtime. is a scene node renderer which handles s. If a references , the renderer creates the displacement/normal map textures and stores them in the and properties.

CPU Queries:
can be set to to also perform a CPU FFT on the CPU. The size of the CPU FFT is defined by . is usually a lot smaller than (e.g. 16). The CPU simulation is only an approximation of the exact simulation on the GPU.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.WaterFlow
member.summary: Defines the direction and speed of water flow.

remarks.para: This class can be used to make the water of a flow in user-defined directions and with user-defined speed.

Defining Flow:
Water flow is defined by three influences:
defines a uniform constant flow which is applied to the whole water surface.
Water flow can also be defined by surface slope of the water surface. The slope is defined by the vertex normals of the water . Water is usually running downhill. defines the speed at which water flows down an inclined water surface.
A texture can be used to define a detailed, complex flow pattern. scales the speed defined by the flow map.

Speed and Normal Strength Limits:
Flow speed from all three influences (base velocity, surface slope and flow map) is summed up and clamped to . The intensity of normal maps should be reduced if the water moves faster. The normal map strength have full strength when the flow speed is zero. The normal map strength is reduced to when the flow speed reaches its maximum ().

Reference frame:
The is relative to the local space of the . The is also relative to the ; it is aligned with the local axes of the node. It fills the local AABB, and the map is always projected top-down.

Rendering Flow:
Water flow is created by scrolling the normal maps of the water into the flow direction. If two points on the water surface have a different flow direction or flow speed, then this creates distortion. To hide the distortions, two layers of normal maps are alternated: One normal map layer fades in, is scrolled and before it gets too distorted it fades out. At the same time a second normal map layer is added but with a half cycle offset. defines the cycle period. The normal map cycling can cause pulsing artifacts. Noise can be used to hide this artifact, by giving each point on the water surface a different cycle offset. defines the scale of the applied noise texture in x and z direction. defines how much noise is applied to each pixel (= how much a cycle can be offset). The noise map itself is always generated automatically.
Limitations: Currently, the does not render when the also uses .

member.summary: Gets or sets the texture which defines the flow direction and speed.
member.value: The texture which defines the flow direction and speed.

remarks.para: The RG channels stores horizontal flow direction. The B channel stores the flow speed. The water pixel shader will apply the flow map flow like this:
Given a flow map value f = (r, g, b), the 3D flow velocity is flowVelocity.xz = (f.rg * 2 - 1) * f.b * FlowMapSpeed. (The component flowVelocity.y is always 0.)
The is also relative to the ; it is aligned with the local axes of the node. It fills the local AABB, and the map is always projected top-down.

member.summary: Gets or sets the cycle duration in seconds of a normal map layer.
member.value: The cycle duration in seconds of a normal map layer

remarks.para: Flow animation is usually created by moving a normal map layer over the water plane. If different pixels move the water plane in different directions, the normal map gets distorted. Therefore, the animation has to alternate between two normal map layers. Each normal map layer is moved and reset while the other normal map is visible. defines how long each normal map layer is shown before it is reset. Too short cycle times can create an unwanted "pulsing" effect. Too long cycle times can create unwanted visible distortions.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.GraphicsScreen
member.summary: Provides the base class for graphics screens, which implement the rendering pipeline and draw game content.

remarks.para:
A graphics screen represents a layer in a 3D application. Multiple screens might be stacked on one another, for example:
The back (first) screen renders a 3D world.
In front of the first screen is another screen that renders the HUD.
In front of these layers is a graphics screen that renders a GUI. For example an "Options Dialog".
To display a graphics screen it must be added to a (see property ). The graphics service renders screens back to front.
Each class that derives from can override the methods and . is usually called once per frame and the screen can update its internal state in this method. is called by the in its method.

Each screen implements its own rendering pipeline by overriding . That means, a screen that renders a 3D world can implement a different render pipeline than a screen that draws the HUD or a GUI on top. Each graphics screen can use its own type of scene management. is called by the when one of its Render-methods is called. Special notes: If a screen is fully covered by another screen, the graphics service might not call . On the other hand, if the application has several s, it can happen that is called several times per frame.
and are usually not called in a frame if the screen is invisible (e.g. if is or if the screen is totally covered by another screen).

The property indicates whether a screen covers the entire view or whether a screen is partially transparent. The property needs to be set by each graphics screen depending on the content which is going to be rendered. The graphics service reads the property to determine which screens need to be rendered.

remarks.para: This value can be used to control time-based animations. In effects it can be used with the semantic.
This value is automatically set by the graphics service. It is computed by continuously summing up the values.

Important:

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.Ephemeris
member.summary: Computes the physically-based properties of sky objects like the sun and the moon.

remarks.para: In astronomy and celestial navigation, an ephemeris (plural: ephemerides; from the Greek word á¼Ï†Î·Î¼ÎµÏÎ¯Ï‚ ephÄ“meris "diary", "journal") gives the positions of astronomical objects in the sky at a given time or times. The class can be used to retrieve the positions of the sun and the moon. It also computes transformations which can be used to convert between different astronomical coordinate system. Further, the light contributions of the sun and the moon are estimated.

The input for all computations are the position (specified using , and ) and the current . All derived values are computed when is called. That means, must be called every time the input properties are changed. It is not called automatically, so must be called at least once.
Following coordinate systems are used. All coordinate system are right-handed and can be used with cartesian coordinates (X, Y, Z) or polar coordinates (latitude, longitude).

Ecliptic Coordinate System:
This coordinate system is relative to the plane defined by the path of the sun or (which is the same) the plane in which the earth moves around the sun. That means, in the ecliptic system the latitude of the sun or the earth is always 0.
Latitude and longitude are 0 at the vernal equinox. Latitude in this space is also called declination. Longitude is also called right ascension.
Regarding Cartesian coordinates, the x and y axes are in the plane of the earth orbit. x is the axis where latitude and longitude are 0, which is equal to the vernal equinox. +z points north. The origin of the coordinate system can be the sun (heliocentric) or the earth (geocentric).

Equatorial Coordinate System:
This coordinate system is relative to the plane defined by the earth's equator. Latitude and longitude are 0 at the vernal equinox.
Regarding Cartesian coordinates, the x and y axes are in the plane of the equator. x is the axis where latitude and longitude are 0, which is equal to the vernal equinox. +y points east. +z points north. The origin of the coordinate system can be the sun (heliocentric) or the earth (geocentric).

Geographic Coordinate System:
This coordinate system is relative to the plane defined by the earth's equator. This system is like the Equatorial system but the longitude is 0 at Greenwich. This means, the difference to the Equatorial system is a constant longitude offset. This coordinate system is well known from school and globes. The properties , are relative to the Geographic Coordinate System.
Regarding Cartesian coordinates, the x and y axes are in the plane of the equator. x is the axis where latitude and longitude are 0, which is in the line of Greenwich. +y points east. +z points north.

World Space:
This coordinate system is relative to a place on the earth. Computer game levels use this coordinate system. It is also known as "Horizontal Coordinate System" or "Horizon Coordinates". The origin of this space is defined by , (in the Geographic coordinate system) and .
Regarding Cartesian coordinates, +x points east, +y points up, -z points north.

member.summary: Computes the sunlight intensity.
member.param: The altitude (elevation) of the observer's position in meters above the mean sea level.

The turbidity, which measures how polluted the air is. The values should be in the range [1.8, 20]. A turbidity of 2 describes a clear day whereas a turbidity of 20 represents thick haze. A commonly used value is 2.2.
The direction from the observer's position to the sun.
The scattered sunlight illuminance (= ambient light, indirect light or "skylight" contribution of the sun) in [lux].

remarks.para: The light values are computed for the earth using NASA data, experimental data and a physically-based model of the atmosphere.

All light values are computed for a cloudless sky. When the sky is cloudy, reduce the direct light and increase the scattered/ambient light. Additionally you will want to increase the ambient light at night to model light pollution.
Thread-Safety: This method is not thread-safe, i.e. it must not be called simultaneously from multiple threads.

remarks.para: This class represents a spectrum of the visible light. The array contains elements. Each element describes the power of a frequency in the range of visible light (380 to 780 nm). The interval between two samples is .

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.Spectrum.ApplyAtmosphericTransmittance(System.Double,System.Double,System.Double,DigitalRune.Graphics.Spectrum,DigitalRune.Graphics.Spectrum)
member.summary: Computes direct and indirect light information when this spectrum passes through the earth's atmosphere.
member.param: The angle between the zenith and the direction of the light source emitting the simulated spectrum in radian.
The simulated atmospheric turbidity in the range [1.8, 20.0]. A turbidity of 2 describes a clear day whereas a turbidity of 20 represents thick haze. A commonly used value is 2.2.
The simulated altitude in meters above mean sea level.
Output: The spectral energy directly from the light source that survives transmission through the atmosphere.
Output: The spectral energy scattered by the atmosphere, which makes up "skylight" (ambient light from the sky).

remarks.para: This method simulates the passage of this spectrum through earth's atmosphere, employing the National Renewable Energy Lab's "Bird model". Two new spectra, representing the direct and scattered irradiance resulting from passage through the atmosphere, are returned.
If the light source is below the horizon, this model returns 0. Thus, it cannot be used to compute twilight.

member.name: M:DigitalRune.Graphics.GraphicsHelper.GetViewNormalizedDistance(DigitalRune.Graphics.SceneGraph.SceneNode,DigitalRune.Graphics.SceneGraph.CameraNode)

overloads.summary: Gets the view-normalized distance ("LOD distance").

member.summary: Calculates the view-normalized distance ("LOD distance") of the specified scene node.
member.returns: The view-normalized distance.

remarks.para: The view-normalized distance is defined as:
distancenormalized = distance / yScale
where distance is the 3D Euclidean distance between the camera and the object. yScale is the second diagonal entry of the projection matrix.
For symmetric perspective projections the above equation is the same as
distancenormalized = distance * tan(fovY / 2)
where fovY is the camera's vertical field-of-view.

In other words, the view-normalized distance is the camera distance times a camera correction factor. The correction factor accounts for the camera field-of-view. The resulting value is inversely proportional to the screen size of the object and independent of the current field-of-view. It can be used to specify LOD distances or similar metrics.

Note that tan(fovY/2) is 1 if the fovY = 90Â°. This means that distance and view-normalized distance are identical for a camera with a vertical field-of-view of 90Â°. (This 90Â° FOV camera is the "reference camera".)
The view-normalized distance is only defined for cameras with perspective projections. The result is undefined for orthographic projections!

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.PackedTexture
member.summary: Defines a texture which has been packed into a texture atlas.

remarks.para: A texture atlas is a large image containing a collection of textures. It is often more efficient to pack multiple textures into a texture atlas which can be treated as a single unit by the graphics hardware. The represents a single texture within the texture atlas.

Tile Sets:
A packed texture can further be divided into tiles (= tile set). A tile set is a collection of images ("sprites" or "tiles"). All tiles have the same size and are packed in a regular grid: defines the number of tiles in x direction and defines the number of tiles in y direction.

2D Animations:
A tile set can be used for 2D animations ("flipbook animations", "sprite sheet animations"): The tile set contains a sequence of images (animation frames). Cycling through the images in rapid succession creates the illusion of movement.

When a tile set is used for animation, the top-left tile contains the first animation frame, the second tile in the upper row contains the second animation frame, and so on. The bottom-right tile contains the last animation frame.

Important: Most renderers require that the animation frames are tightly packed and the tile set does not contain empty tiles. For example, an animation consisting of 3 frames can be packed as a 1x3 or 3x1 tile set, but not as 2x2!

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.PostProcessor
member.summary: Performs scene post-processing, like filtering, color manipulation, etc.

remarks.para: A post-processor reads a source texture, which must be specified in the property of the . It processes the source texture and writes its output to a render target, which must be specified in the property of the . The render target can be to write into the back buffer of the graphics device.
The post-processor will always call . for the specified render target - that means it is not necessary that the render target is currently set in the graphics device.

In general, the and the must not reference the same render target. Only if the post-processor uses multi-pass rendering internally, or if the post-processor is a consisting of several post-processors, then the source texture and the render target can reference the same object. That means, it depends on the used post-processor whether it is possible or not. If it is not possible, and the same render target is used as the source texture and the target, then XNA will throw an exception.
Post-processors can be chained together: See class for more information.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.Blur.IsAnisotropic
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether to use an anisotropic filter kernel.
member.value: if the filter kernel is anisotropic; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.para: By default an isotropic filter kernel is used, which means that the filter is equal in all dimensions. The specified filter is equally applied to all pixels in x- and y-direction.

In contrast, an anisotropic filter kernel is adjusted for each pixel. Surface position and normal are read from the G-buffer and the filter kernel is scaled and rotated to match the underlying surface.
Currently, anisotropic filtering is only supported for separable filter kernels. must be set to .

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.Blur.IsBilateral
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether joint bilateral filtering (= edge-aware filtering) is enabled.
member.value: if joint bilateral filtering is enabled; otherwise, . The default value is .

remarks.para: Joint bilateral filtering (= edge-aware filtering) can be enabled to blur surfaces in a 3D scene and prevent filtering across object boundaries and depth discontinuities.

Bilateral filtering means that the filter kernels is only applied to pixels that are close (e.g. geometric similarity or photometric similarity). In this case the sample weights (e.g. the Gaussian weights) are scaled by a range function. Joint or cross bilateral filtering means that the range function is applied to a second image instead of the image that is being processed.

When is enabled the depth of each sample is read from the depth buffer (G-buffer 0). The sample weights are weighted based on the depth difference to the current pixel. Samples near the current pixel (small depth difference) contribute more than distant samples (large depth difference).

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.Blur.EdgeSoftness
member.summary: Gets or sets the edge softness for bilateral filtering.
member.value: The edge softness for bilateral filtering in world space units. The default value is 0.1.

remarks.para: When is enabled, an edge-aware blur is used to avoid blurring over depth discontinuities. The sensitivity of the edge-aware blur is defined by . The value is the max allowed depth difference of two pixel in world space units (at 1 unit in front of the camera). Pixels that closer than this threshold are blurred together; pixels which are farther apart are ignored.
Decrease the value to make edges crisper. Increase to make edges softer.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.Blur.DepthScaling
member.summary: Gets or sets a value that controls how scene depth influences the filter scale. (Only used by anisotropic or bilateral blurs.)
member.value: The depth scaling value in the range [0, 1]. The default value is 0.7.

remarks.para: This property is only relevant for anisotropic () or bilateral () filters.
Setting to 0 disables depth scaling. The filter radius is constant over the entire scene.
If is 1, then the filter radius is scaled with scene depth, getting smaller in the distance. The filter radius at a distance of 1 unit is 100%. The filter radius at infinity is 0.
The value can be between 0 and 1, for example: If is 0.7, the filter radius decreases slowly with scene depth. The filter radius at a distance of 1 unit is 100%. The filter radius at infinity is 30%.

member.name: P:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.Blur.IsSeparable
member.summary: Gets or sets a value indicating whether the configured blur filter is separable.
member.value: if this instance is separable; otherwise, .
member.remarks: Filters like a box blur or a Gaussian blur are separable. This means, the result of an n x n blur is equal to an n x 1 blur followed by an 1 x n blur. If this flag is set, this processor will perform a blur pass in two steps: First, the image blurred using the configured . Then, the x and y values of the are swapped and the blurred image is blurred again.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.ColorCorrectionFilter
member.summary: Modifies an image using a color lookup table (a.k.a. "color grading").

remarks.para: This processor uses a 3D volume texture as a color lookup table to transform the colors of an image. can be set directly. But it is usually easier to load it from a 2D texture. The method creates a default 2D lookup texture (without any color transformations). Use to convert a 2D lookup texture to a 3D lookup texture.

Workflow:
To define a color lookup texture, the artist can use following steps:
Make a screenshot of the game and load it in Photoshop.
Load the default lookup texture in Photoshop.
Copy the lookup texture in Photoshop and paste it into the document with the screenshot.
Apply color manipulations to the screenshot and the lookup texture. (Usually using adjustment layers.)
Select the lookup table inside the screenshot. (Select the layer with the lookup table and use the menu Select | Load Selection.)
Select the menu Edit | Copy Merged to select the lookup table including the adjustments.
Paste the lookup texture into a new image and save it.
(Of course the color lookup texture can also be created in any other image editing tool.)

Interpolation between lookup textures:
Optionally, you can set a second lookup texture in and use to interpolate between both. This can be used to gradually change the color correction when transitioning to a new zone in the game level. If only or is set, then one lookup texture is applied with the specified and is ignored.

member.name: T:DigitalRune.Graphics.PostProcessing.HdrFilter
member.summary: Performs HDR tone mapping supporting bloom/glare, dynamic eye adaption and scotopic vision.

remarks.para: This post-processor is also responsible for converting the input texture from an HDR format (usually HdrBlendable) to an LDR format. Therefore, the surface format in is set to Color.

This post-processor stores luminance information of a frame for use in the next frame. The information is stored with the currently active camera node. When there is a cut in the scene (i.e. a new level is loaded or the view changes significantly), the method of the camera node needs to be called to reset the luminance information. Further, this post-processor expects that it is called once per frame for a certain camera node. It might not work as expected if it is called several times per frame (e.g. to process different views using the same camera).

Exposure and Middle Gray
The computes the average brightness of the scene and applies a brightness scale factor ("exposure") so that the average brightness of the final image is equal to . That means, if you are in a dark cave, the filter will make the image a lot brighter. If you are in a white dessert, it will make the image darker. Both images will have the same average brightness defined by . The brightness scale factor is limited by and . That means, if you set = = 1, then there will be no brightness change. If your scene is very bright or very dark, then you have to adjust . Use and to limit the allowed brightness changes.

Night Tone mapping with Blue Shift (Scotopic Vision):
The human visual system perceives low luminance scenes (e.g. night scenes) different than well-lit scenes. Under daylight the cones in the human eye dominate and create the normal color image (photopic vision). The cones start to lose sensitivity at about 3.4 cd/mÂ², and the rods start to get more dominant. A dark scene perceived by the rods (scotopic vision) is monochrome with a blue shift. This supports physically-based night tone mapping. Per default it is disabled. The blue shift is controlled using the properties , , and . Depending on the lighting in the scene, might need to be scaled. It is also possible to use a different color for a more dramatic effect. and might also need to be changed if the scene is not lit using physically-based light intensities and lighting models.

remarks.para: The blue shift depends on the average scene luminance. If the average scene luminance is equal to to , then the resulting image is the average of the normal image and a fully blue shifted image.

The default value of is 0.04. This value is suitable for a scene that is rendered using physically-based lighting, i.e. light intensities are based on real world light intensities and luminance values are in cd/mÂ². If the scene lighting is not physically-based, then this value needs to be adapted.

remarks.para: This value defines the luminance range where the blue shift is applied. For a human eye and physically-based lighting, this value should be 1. With this default value, the blue shift is 100% when the average scene luminance is 0. The blue shift is 50% when the luminance is equal to . The blue shift is approx. 1% when the luminance is x 100. (The cones in the human eye start to lose their sensitivity at 3.4 cd/mÂ².)

is proportional to the luminance range on a logarithmic scale. That means, if the is 1, the 1% point is at x 100. If the is set to 0.5, the 1% point is at x 10 (= 1000.5). If the is set to 2, the 1% point is at x 10000 (= 1002).

member.summary: Upscales an input texture.

remarks.para: This post-processor reads the low-resolution and increases the resolution to match the .

The supports different modes (see property ). and are basic upsampling modes that do not take the original geometry in account. and are "edge-aware" modes that try to maintain the original geometry and prevent blurred edges. The "edge-aware" modes require that the depth buffer is set in the render context (see property ) and the low-resolution copy of the depth buffer needs to be stored in renderContext.Data[RenderContextKey.DepthBufferHalf].
Optionally, a can be set in the . In this case the input texture is combined (alpha-blended) to the scene texture and the combined result is output by the pixel shader.
